reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s key conditioning premise: that “mostly-great futures are a narrow target” (imported from “no easy eutopia”), which is central because much of the essay’s pessimism about WAM-convergence and its reliance on trade/threats is motivated by target-narrowness. If target-narrowness were substantially weakened, many downstream worries would be less pressing, so centrality is high. However, the critique mainly argues under-specification and offers an alternative intuition (many axiologies are coarse-grained), rather than directly engaging the prior essay’s case for no-easy-eutopia or showing that, under a realistic moral-uncertainty mixture, most value lies in a large basin of near-optimal futures. Because it’s more a challenge to justification/robustness than a refutation, strength is moderate. Its main claims are broadly plausible (underspecification here; some theories tolerate wide outcome-sets once constraints are met), though it arguably underestimates how the position explicitly leans on fussy population ethics/aggregation issues and how even ‘rights/agency/suffering constraints’ can be demanding at cosmic scales; hence high but not perfect correctness. It is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little to no filler.
title: The paper overstates the narrowness of the moral target
